Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2008 12:46PM omlivewbc wrote: I am very anal about reading and cross referencing my own reports.  After being dx with a lung met when my mets journey began, we did a bone scan and a PET.  All of the areas that lit up on the bone scan correspond to areas that lit up on the PET.  So for me the results were quite consistent. Isn't it something the way our test results can vary?  We come together in hopes of benefiting from other experiences.  There are so many variables and so many different tests.  However, in this case based on your test results it sounds like a safe bet to rely on the bonescan.  I will add that I recently had a spine MRI to check for mets on spinal cord.  There were no mets found on cord, but the spine itself showed mets on a couple the original areas.  Both rad and med onc currently feel this is possibly an inactive spot and not reason to adjust tx at this time.  But we will definitely be on the lookout when I scan again next month.  We'll see. Hoping your treatment goes well!

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2007 11:13AM omlivewbc wrote: Lisa, I remember a couple of months ago when I was first dx with brain mets I read a posting on bcmets.org where brain lesions were attacked individually even though multiple lesions existed.  As you may have already figured out, there seem to be more brain mets ladies on that site than on this one.  I can't think of the lady's name right now but I remember I had done a search on brain mets and read a gazilion entries.  Anyway, this particular lady had decided she definitely did not want WBR and chose to instead identify the lesions that posed a significant threat and radiate them with a series of treatments with success.  I believe she used cyberknife but not sure.  I may have saved that post off on my home computer.  I'm at a different computer right now but will check later for you, hon.  But for now I wanted to at least send you this so maybe you can search and try to dig that posting out if you'd like. I realize what you need right now are some options and encouraging info.  I pray for and look forward to something coming through soon.  My heart is heavy for you today.  Please try to enjoy your baby's birthday.  (((HUGS))) Olivia

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2007 09:49PM omlivewbc wrote: LuAnn Just read the article online.  (Thanks, ADK, for posting the link).  I literally went to three different stores today looking for this More magazine.  I would like to financially support a magazine that would research and publish an article in October that focuses on stage IV!  Since I couldn't find a copy to purchase, I read the article online.  How awesome that you were able to contribute!  You continue to inspire and now you're reaching an even broader audience. Since I was in the stores anyway I went ahead and browsed through Ladies Home Journal, Good Housekeeping and Essence magazine.  Of course each of these fine publications carried some type of bc article in their Oct issue.  I was so saddened by the disregard for any mention of a bc stage less than II.  I was once stage II seven years ago and would have sucked up stories such as those featured in these articles.  Now, I get out the big "Not Applicable" stamp and hunger for stories from stage IV ladies.  So thank you. Olivia

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2008 09:54PM omlivewbc wrote: Abraxane and Avastin worked for my lung/bone mets as my first line tx.  I started out bi-weekly Abraxane and then switched to weekly.  My white cell count was much more cooperative with the weekly for me.  Both of my oncs agreed that lower weekly doses is be the Abraxane standard.  May be a point worth exploring further, perhaps with your new onc?  I did experience some annoying neurapathy in my fingers with some relief from neurontin, and also an icky fungal infection going on in all fingernails.  But other than that it really was quite doable.  I worked throughout treatment.  Toward the end I did develop a bloodclot in my arm, one of the noted side effects of the Avastin.  So do please listen to your body during treatment.  There used to be a very long thread on this tx combo with a number of success stories.  Wishing you

Posts.Content: omlivewbc wrote: I've made the difficult decision to switch oncs. I want the onc who's been my second opinion since my mets dx in Jan 07 to now be my lead onc. I'm 100% convinced I'll be in better hands with her. She's at a major cancer center affiliated with an academic insitution and hospital and we've already discussed more tx options than I have heard about from my current onc. I have been with my current onc since my initial bc dx in 1999 at age 32. We have a great relationship. I just don't think he's aggressive enough or that he has a broad variety of treatment options in mind for me. Or that he uses the proper tools to diagnose and monitor me. I don't think he's used to assertive 40 yr old patients who do their own research and wants her doc to do everything possible to keep her around for her two young children. His practice is fairly small and I very rarely see anyone close to my age in his office. Most of the tests he has ordered for me have been at my request, and I had to really work to convince him. That's exhausting and scary. When I was coughing incessantly back in Nov he gave me an xray which came back clean and sent me on my way. If I hadn't insisted on further testing, I wouldn't know I am now stage IV. And I had to absolutely insist on the brain MRI I had last month that dx a lesion in the brain. And also, although he is a sweetheart, the bedside manner of his office staff sucks. I want out of there as it becomes increasingly difficult to resist the urge to slap his staff when they talk down to me. I'm currently being treated for lung/bone mets with weekly chemo. I've already scheduled my first treatment with my new onc in a few weeks and need to inform my current onc of this decision when I see him this week. He knows I've been using this major cancer center as a 2nd opinion, but will be surprised to learn that I plan to break up with him. But the truth is I think my outlook and prognosis will be much better in someone else's hand. I'd be interested in advice from anyone who has also switched oncs mid-treatment. What to say? Is it a good idea to have the old and new onc have a conversation? How to deal with the anxiety of ending this 7 year relationship? Olivia Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Advice on Switching Oncs omlivewbc jacqniel

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2007 12:06PM omlivewbc wrote: b445 I just read through your experience here and I can totally relate to this rough ride you're on.  Sorry you're going through it.  That must have been one deep sleep you were in to have turned over on your port side.  Wow, that must have hurt like.... I had three ports placed during my Abraxane/Avastin treatment this year.  Infections, poor healing, just a mess.  And quite a nuisance when one is trying to focus on the treatment and not the port which is supposed to make treatments easier!!  During my last placement the surgeon loaded me up on stitches on both the old and new incisions and we kept them in for two weeks to allow extra healing.  That finally seemed to work.  Left an ugly scar though, but really who cares.  I hope you read this in time to discuss this option with your doc.

Posts.Content: omlivewbc wrote: We have quite a few bc sisters out here currently in need of encouragement. I have my days too. I know I'm not the only member who keeps my own copies of postings that meant something to me -- information and/or encouragement. There are some very encouraging stories mixed in the various threads. I thought it would be nice for some of us to capture some of those encouraging stories in one place (in addition to the amazing 14 yr mets survivor story recently moved up!). I'll go first.... I'm currently being treated for lung/bone mets. Only three months into treatment and my mets are already difficult to detect on my scans. Encouraging part number one is that it appears I'm on my way back to NED. Encouraging part number two is that I had a seven year remission before my recent mets dx. Of course we thought I was cured after 7 yrs stage II. But if I had to have a recurrence, I'm glad to know it was held off for 7 years. I was 32 when first dx. I'm a single mother of two young girls and plan to be around for quite some time! Olivia Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Gathering Encouraging Stories omlivewbc Janice54
